musicalLanguage.description: The most famous odd-meter jazz piece ever recorded. The 5/4 groove splits naturally into 3+2, with the left hand vamp anchoring the feel while the right hand carries the cool, understated melody. Paul Desmond wrote it; Dave Brubeck's quartet made it immortal.
musicalLanguage.structure: Vamp-based — A section (Ebm groove), 8 bars shown
keyMoments: Bar 1: The iconic Ebm7-Bbm7 vamp begins — feel the 3+2 pulse
Bar 3-4: Melody enters with that cool, floating quality over the vamp
Bar 7-8: Melodic tension peaks before resolving back to the vamp
teachingGoals: Feel 5/4 time as 3+2 — count ONE-two-three ONE-two
Left-hand vamp independence while right hand plays melody
Minor 7th chord voicings in Eb minor
styleTips: Keep the left hand vamp steady and even — it is the entire groove
Right hand melody should float above the vamp, relaxed and cool
Do not rush the 5/4 — let each beat have its full weight

measures.teachingNote: Ebm7 to Bbm7 vamp. Feel the 3+2 split: dotted half + half = 5 beats.

measures.leftHand: Eb3 Gb3 Bb3:h. Bb2 Db3 F3:h

measures.leftHand: Eb3 Gb3 Bb3:h. Bb2 Db3 F3:h
measures.teachingNote: Melody peaks at Eb5 and falls. The quarter rest at the end lets it breathe.

measures.leftHand: Eb3 Gb3 Bb3:h. Bb2 Db3 F3:h
measures.teachingNote: Five quarter notes — one per beat. The melody fills the entire bar.

measures.teachingNote: Resolution back to Bb and Eb. The vamp cycle is ready to repeat.
